newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean party leader kicks off presidential race.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean party leader kicks off presidential race.

text.p: South Korea's ruling party chairman Lee Hong-koo on Tuesday kicked off a race for the presidency by challenging other party elders to policy debates.
Lee, due to step down as party chairman on Thursday, told reporters he would campaign to win the party's nomination for presidential elections in December.
"The time has come to make a choice," he said.
"I will concentrate my efforts on providing new leadership for the people and revitalising the party to win the presidential elections.
"Selection of a new leader must be different from the method in the past. We should break away from politics of money and factional forces. It should be through active policy debates."

Nine party leaders are thought to be in the running to replace President Kim Young-sam after his five year term expires next February. But Lee, widely seen as a protege of Kim, is the first to make public his presidential ambitions.
Political analysts said Kim, barred by the constitution from seeking a second term, would try to influence the battle among the candidates from behind the scenes.

However Kim promised a free race for his party's presidential nominee last month when he apologised for the forced passage of a labour law and a loans scandal that badly damaged his political credibility.
The analysts said Lee's move would encourage other presidential aspirants to come forward.
Candidates have been reluctant to declare their ambition too early and make Kim a lame duck.
"In the one-term presidential system, the lame-duck phenomenon is unavoidable in the last year of any presidency," said Moon Chung-in, political science professor at Seoul's Yonsei University.
Moon said Kim's political dominance had prevented party elders from expanding their power bases.
"The most pressing task for President Kim is to make sure his ruling party wins the election," he said. "An early race for the presidency will help foster a national-level leader," he said.

Lee lacks his own influence at the grass roots of the party but commands respect as an intellectual. Educated at Yale, he was a professor of politics, ambassador to Britain and prime minister before becoming party chairman.

Lee was tipped as the front-runner to win the ruling party's mandate until nearly a month of strikes sparked by the forced passage of a controversial labour law last December cost him his job as party chairman.

Led by Lee, ruling party members rammed the bill through the National Assembly in a dawn session while opposition deputies slept. Kim was forced to send it back to parliament, and on Monday a revised bill was passed.
